headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: DOJ Sues Texas over Immigration Law; Ousted Harvard President Speaks Out; Judge and Officials Attacked in Courtroom. Aired 9:30-10a ET

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Endorsing Donald Trump before we even see a single vote cast. What are your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST AND ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: That's what -- that's what drives me crazy. I mean, look, this is a robust field. Donald Trump is in poll position clearly, but he's not a frontrunner like past frontrunners. This isn't the second return of Grover Cleveland, you know, you know, just to drop the kind of nerdish reference that I'm fond of. This is somebody who tried to overturn an election in the United States on the basis of a lie. And the fact that the Republican leadership is all rallying around him, including Tom Emmer, the whip, who Trump savaged just a few weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Seriously. Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: It shows a lack of confidence in the voters, it shows a degree of cowardice, they're all trying to get on the Trump train, ahead of a single vote. And it means that they're enabling and complicit in Trump's attempt to whitewash history regarding his actions to the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I want to talk to you a little bit about DeSantis in Iowa. And there was concern -- he brought his young son and there was these negative ads. He told -- basically people were like, look, your son is parroting ads after watching like football games for the last couple of holiday weekends, and he asked DeSantis how to clean up politics so that it can teach his son to do better. What's the answer?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Look --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Negative ads work, right, though?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Negative ads work.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: And people from Richard Nixon on down will tell you that people vote out of fear not out of love. But I think that is what -- we should aspire to something higher.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes. AVLON

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: And I think when you have that sense of the civic firmament that connects our politics, realizing that politics is history in the present tense, then it kind of ennobles the entire debate. When you have people that just treat you to smash mouth politics and see who can out-fearmonger the other --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: That denigrates our history. That denigrates American democracy. And so I think it's about us all responding, calling to our own higher -- better angels of our nature, but also rewarding the candidates to speak to our hopes and not our fears.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes, the polarization gets worse and worse. There's lots of violent rhetoric that happens. I mean it just deteriorates, right?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: We see it every day.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Last and very, very quick question and a quick question because I'm -- I don't have as much time as I want.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Shoot.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: The -- John, hush. OK, John's over here laughing.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I'm taking it up. Immigration.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: This is a huge issue.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's a polarizing issue. It is a real issue that needs to be dealt with.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: It is a real issue.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Point blank, Democrat, Republican, independent, doesn't matter what you are.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: A hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: The Republicans in the House in particular, you see the Republicans working with the Democrats. You see the Democrats making concessions with the Republicans in the Senate. But the House is a different story. House Republicans making all of these demands, saying the Democrats aren't playing ball. Do the House Republicans want this to go through, because it's not going to go through as it is.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: I think our own reporting and Jake's interview with Speaker Johnson the other day indicates that they would rather have the issue than to solve it. And I think Democrats have come around to the fact that they have to deal with it and they've got to change asylum laws. It's not just throwing money at the problem.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right. You said the issue -- and to solve it, they don't want to solve it, but they don't want to solve it right now, correct, during the Biden administration?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: They don't want to solve it with a -- with a Democratic president because they're afraid he might get credit, which says that they're concerned about the urgency of this issue, which is real and urgent.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: They're willing to play politics with it and let it continue to fester in order to get a political win rather than dealing with it, which is really what, remember, folks are elected to do. Deal with the problem. Don't just demagogue it.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And it's been going on for decades and decades. Every single president going through this.John Avlon, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Sara. (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: John.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: This morning the Department of Justice is suing Texas over its controversial immigration law that gives local law enforcement the authority to arrest migrants and gives judges the ability to remove migrants to Mexico. The DOJ argues this law undercuts the federal government.CNN's Priscilla Alvarez, at the White House, where this happens in the middle of this back and forth between the White House and Republicans in Congress and Republicans and Democrats in the Senate.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Priscilla Alvarez, at the White House watching this for us. Priscilla, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: The president of MIT is laying out a four part plan after heavy and harsh criticism of her congressional testimony on anti- Semitism. Is it enough to keep her job as two others have lost theirs.And a Nevada judge is recovering after a defendant attacked her in the -- look at this -- good gracious -- in the middle of a hearing. The shocking video and the new charges the suspect is facing this morning. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [09:45:06] BERMAN: All right, today Reverend Al Sharpton is set to lead protests outside Harvard donor Bill Ackman's office in New York. Ackman was a vocal critic of ousted Harvard President Claudine Gay and her handling of anti-Semitism on the Harvard campus and her initial response to the Hamas terror attack in Israel. Gay spoke out for the first time since her resignation this week in a "New York Times" op-ed acknowledging that she made mistakes during her congressional testimony last month and making clear that she believes the campaign against her was driven, at least in part, by her skin color. This is what she wrote, "my inbox has been flooded with invective, including death threats. I've been called the n-word more than I care to count." She also defended, for the first time, her academic writings against plagiarism allegations. CNN's Matt Egan following all of this for us now. Matt.

utterances.speaker: MATT EGAN, CNN REPORTER
utterances.sentences: You know, John, this is Claudine Gay punching back against her critics, arguing that they relied on lies and insults instead of reasoned arguments. And this is a not-so-subtle jab at billionaire Bill Ackman, who led this campaign to end her presidency, a successful campaign we should note.Now, remember, Gay was the first black president in Harvard's nearly 400 year history. And clearly she believes that race played a role in also making this the shortest presidency in Harvard's history. Of her critics she wrote, and I quote, "they recycled tired racial stereotypes about black talent and temperament. They pushed a false narrative of indifference and incompetence." Now, meanwhile, there are new question being raised about the Harvard Corporation. Now that is the powerful but secretive board that really calls the shots at the university because clearly the past few months have been a nightmare for Harvard and there's a lot of people wondering about how the Harvard Corporation allowed it to go this badly. I spoke to Yale Professor Jeff Sonnenfeld. He told me that the Harvard Corporation deserved a failing grade and he called for a membership shakeup there. Listen to what Jeff said. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JEFF SONNENFELD, YALE UNIVERSITY PROFESSOR AND HARVARD GRADUATE
utterances.sentences: Harvard is a critical global beacon of truth and, of course, a national treasure. And for them to be so tone deaf to criticism was remarkable.They have damaged the brand significantly. So, they deserve a generous D. They need to go through some change there in terms of the membership of the board. That they perhaps need some more diversity of thought in there. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Now, Sonnenfeld called out in particular Penny Pritzker, who leads the Harvard Corporation. Remember, she's a democratic donor. She's a current Biden official. And he said that her silence over the last few weeks has been, quote, "deafening." Bill Ackman and other Harvard donors have called for Penny Pritzker to step down. But Harvard says that Penny Pritzker is rejecting those calls. She has no plans to step down.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: What's happening down Mass Ave. at MIT because the president of MIT was also part of that controversial congressional testimony.

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: That's right. You know, it was almost exactly a month ago three college presidents testified before Congress about anti-Semitism. Right now only Sally Kornbluth, the president of MIT, is the only one who still is in power. And within minutes of Claudine Gay's resignation hitting the news the other day, Bill Ackman put out a tweet saying, "et tu Sally?" Clearly trying to turn the attention to the MIT president.Now, she is detailing efforts to address anti-Semitism and tension on campus. She put out a new memo acknowledging that the Israel-Hamas war has caused, quote, "deep pain around the world and at MIT," and says it is an ongoing source of tension at the school. She wrote, quote, "I am working to use every lever able to address conflict on our campus, enhance the tenor of our discourse and help us to find improved ways to live and work together here at MIT." She did lay out four new steps that they're taking, including efforts to understand the ways to address free expression versus hate speech, also trying to get a better sense for how students feel about safety on campus and making sure that diversity programs effectively meet campus needs. But nothing that she put out in this memo is going to silence her critics, John.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right, Matt Egan, following this from the very beginning.Matt, thank you. Good work on this.

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Thanks, John.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: This morning a Nevada judge and marshal are recovering after a brutal courtroom attack  that was all, as you might imagine in court, caught on camera. Now the defendant, accused of beating them, and you'll have to watch what happens here as a judge is talking to the defendant. All of a sudden, out of the right side of the camera, you are going to see what happened as he jumps across the table -- excuse me, the judge's bench and attacks her.Let's get to CNN's Mike Valerio. Mike, walk us through the video that we are about to see?

utterances.speaker: MIKE VALERIO, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Sara, what did you say before the break, good golly miss molly? I don't think, though all the "Law and Order" episodes that we have seen, through all the court cases we have covered over the years, we have witnessed anything like this.So, this man, a 30-year-old, who's a three-time felon, Deobra Redden, he is being sentenced for alleged battery. The defense counsel is saying, you know what, we'd like our client to have probation. The judge says something to the effect of, well, I think that your client needs a taste of something different. And this is what happens. Watch. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JUDGE MARY KAY HOLTHUS, CLARK COUNTY DISTRICT COURT
utterances.sentences: History. In accordance with the laws in the state of Nevada, this court --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (EXPLETIVE DELETED).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Whoa, whoa, whoa, hey.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Whoa. Hey.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (EXPLETIVE DELETED).(INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Judge (EXPLETIVE DELETED). (INAUDIBLE) (EXPLETIVE DELETED).(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That video was just -- I've never seen anything like it. It is incredible. And I'm sure there will be changes in that courtroom and for his life at 30-years-old. After doing that, you're going to face a lot more charges.Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: VALERIO
utterances.sentences: No problem.
